awd_titl_txt: Control of Rydberg Interactions and Exotic States of Matter
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports the study of an exotic type of atom (so-called "Rydberg atoms") in which an electron orbits the nucleus at an unusually large distance from the nucleus . The characteristics of these atoms can be changed by changing the orbit of the electron, making them "tunable." One of the most important properties of these atoms is that when the electron is excited to a very large-sized orbit using laser light, a Rydberg atom can interact with other Rydberg atoms at macroscopic distances, on the order of microns. The interaction range is over 1,000 times larger than for typical atom-atom interactions. These unique ultralong-range interactions have many uses in exploring fundamental aspects of quantum mechanics as well as applications that exploit the unique features of quantum mechanics that can be used for quantum engineering. For example, these interactions can be utilized to put collections of atoms into quantum mechanically entangled states, that is, states where the collection of atoms acts as a single "super atom" which interacts with light in an enhanced manner.  These types of states have many uses in the area of quantum information science and quantum sensing. 

In this project, the group will investigate how to manipulate the interactions between Rydberg atoms with electric and magnetic fields in order to use them for quantum engineering and fundamental studies of quantum mechanics. They will study how magnetic and electric fields can be used to manipulate the topology of Rydberg atom-Rydberg atom interaction potentials. These interactions will be studied using multi-color excitation of Rydberg atoms at ultracold temperatures (T<1mK), and quantitative comparisons between theory and experiments will be carried out. The topology of the potentials will be investigated in terms of gauge potentials. Dephasing rates of excited super atoms will be studied. Ground state atom- Rydberg atom molecules will also be studied. Cesium Rydberg atoms excited in an ultracold gas can be viewed as impurities to which an electron is bound. These artificial impurities can be used to investigate the physics of defect scattering in a controlled fashion which is particularly important in semiconductors. These studies can lead to investigations of highly correlated phenomena in quantum degenerate gases such as rotons, solitons and super solids.

por.por_cntn:
In this project, we discovered a new kind of triatomic ultralong-ranged Rydberg molecule and verified its existence experimentally.  These molecules are formed when a highly excited Rydberg electron centered on an atom is able to interact with a pair of nearby ground state atoms. The work required the development of a spin dependent Hamiltonian to describe the system. The new aspect of the triatomic ultralong-range Rydberg molecule is that it is anisotropic, i.e. its energy states depend upon the relative positions of its two ground state constituents. Similarly, we investigated and modeled anisotropic interactions between two nearby Rydberg atoms polarized by an electric field. These studies are important for developing Rydberg atoms for quantum technologies. Rydberg atoms are tunable quantum systems as their properties depend strongly on the quantum state that is excited and external fields that can be applied. Since it is difficult to uniformly fabricate large numbers of artificial quantum systems and it is difficult to significantly change the properties of most natural quantum systems, Rydberg atoms have grown in importance for quantum technologies. An understanding of Rydberg atom interactions and molecule formation is essential for mitigating dephasing in Rydberg atom quantum sensors and for understanding Rydberg atom quantum simulators. The work done during this project was presented in six journal publications and one thesis, which led to a Ph.d. for the student working on the project. The work was further disseminated in fourteen talks at international conferences, workshops and institutions around the world, including six invited talks. To further expand the field of Rydberg atom physics and reach a broader audience of students, the PI co-organized two international conferences on Rydberg atom physics that generated two special issues on Rydberg atom physics published in Journal of Physics B. The PI also took part in three summer schools to teach graduate students and postdocs about Rydberg atom physics with an emphasis on Rydberg atom interactions and molecule formation. Aside from the senior student on the project, four other graduate students participated.  An international student visited for six months and also participated in the project.
